commentBody: I found that difficult.  Great clues.

OMG please don't tell me HELENE is in today's puzzle!!
(Think of the whole new raft of clues you would have had a week later...)

Once again the NW was the last to fall, mainly because I have no idea what BADBEAT has to do with poker. I often seem to struggle with that quadrant...

Nice puzzle Jake,
I had Selena instead of Selene and didn't remember qdoba, and because of this couldn't figure out mosquito net.  Overall, a good and challenging puzzle.

This puzzle was my 1,000th Gold Star for my streak. I really enjoyed it ü•π

I invited my friends over and we all worked on it together. I am so grateful for crossword puzzles for fostering connection, I love asking people for help on clues that play to their particular niche. I have learned so much from the smart and passionate people in my life, and I am happy to have found a way to make this usually solitary hobby a social one. 

Thanks for all the puns, the word play, and the learning. I‚Äôm so incredibly grateful for the distinctly human urge to make and solve puzzles. I‚Äôm looking forward to 1,000 more ü§çüñ§
Solid puzzle, though I had a gimme that I might not have otherwise gotten, as I flew out of CHOPIN en route to Berlin a week ago today

== Interdep Memo ==

To: Recdep; Minitrue
From: Miniplenty
Date: 26/9/84

Dayorder: All bb anterev records rectified, fullwise. Mention brand* of aperitif bb invented. Gave ppls of Oceania to liberate them of oldthink, promote crimestop.

Teledep ads Fri.

Stock Oct 1.

* "VICTORY LAPSE"

/cc/ Emudep

No complaints. This puzzle was mEaTY as I struggled with it and, finally, ZESTY when I got it solved.

I‚Äôve never heard of Q DOBA in my life. East Coast thing? Mid West? 

And, are we sure [Who‚Äôs cutting onions?] should get the question mark treatment? DICER seems like an extremely literal answer. Not a punny one. I suppose, because the phrase seldom used literally, the literal answer becomes the pun?

Great puzzle. Thanks a bunch, Jake Bunch

Interesting puzzle, how if you worked the short words and the crossed, you could fill the grid in a smooth and even descent, like window shades. And so that happened and [sad Chopin music] still I did not get the gold for my country, Ezralandia. 

Well, it was actually the very first letter. HAD BEAT / HONE IN. As in when one team has another team beat, but the other team manages to eke out a win. That's when it really hurts.  "With a hand like this, he thought, the whole table he had beat." So he bets everything he has and before you know it, tears of blood are streaming down his cheeks and James Bond is wearing a quiet, almost rueful smile, as if the Vesper he was sipping had suddenly grown rather zesty, to die for, even... "Hone in" is what you tell your barber to do for your ducktail, or your fade, or whatever kind of cut you have in mind. So "H" works, yeah?

That's my excuse, O people of Ezramania, may you find it within your hearts to grant me another opportunity to win tomorrow; I promise you victory laps, and I will answer every chant of "Go Team Go!" with a "Let's Roll!" and my heart will beat a seism that would a zillionaire's ego into a zillion pieces, some bone-in, others not so much, like Attila the Hun put through a dicer, probably untested for such uses. "Are you in all the way?" I will ask, as I watch the dicer CHOP IN two the zillionaire's little sea legs, and yes, people of Ezralandia, with gusto I will win gold. I won't forget: it's on my to-do list.

I thought we might have a Friday rebus when I couldn't fit HOUR IN LINE in 54A



TIL QDOBA but the crosses made it easy, even if it didn't look right.

So far today I've survived the crossword puzzle and the fringes of Helene. We've had rain and some wind, which is going to continue for a while, but nothing else so far.

Good puzzle, thanks, Jake.

No problems with the puzzle, and it was challenging and do-able, appropriate for a Friday.  But It felt like a slog to me, few aha! moments.  Maybe that reflected my mood - I had watched the Oakland A's last home game ever, and what a sad moment that was - a billionaire and a sports league shafting a blue-collar city and sports fans who deserve far better.  One of the few highlights here was to learn about PEA; my guess had been soy.

Should Andrzej appear today, he may appreciate that CHOPIN was a gimme for me today as was SELENE. The rest had to be teased out. 

Nice puzzle. Somewhat faster than normal but a decent workout. 

SEALEGS brought a smile 

Thanks

What a puzzle!!!  Every time the light went on and I saw a fill it was a SEISM of delight.  Simple fills with lots of choices (no, not arborio, BASMATI) so the crosses were tightly locked when they worked, and the whole construction was rock solid.  I gave myself a pass on two look-ups‚Äîif we have QDOBAs around here, I never saw one, and I abhor cooking shows, but otherwise I just kept on truckin' til I WONGOLD.

Dire need of distraction tonight, and you got me through it, Jake Bunch. Take a couple of VICTORYLAPS.  Thank you, and l am looking forward to your third.

Wow. When I did my first pass, I had almost nothing. I thought I would not be able to finish without autocheck. In the end I managed to fill the grid on my own though - well, almost, as I looked up FAA, IRONCHEF and AMA (why could this not have been clued the Reddit way, as usual! Because it's Friday). With a puzzle as hard as this I simply needed a few more crosses to get going past the 10 or 15 answers I was reasonably sure of initially.

CHOPIN was a gimme, obviously. Btw, I'm not a fan of the name, for this particular airport. It is located in the Okƒôcie district of Warsaw, and it is one of the oldest airports in this country - it is not only an important transport hub but also a piece of Polish history. It was simply known as "Okƒôcie" for decades. Then in the 1990s for promotional reasons it was renamed. Can you imagine renaming your oldest US airport, College Park?. The managers wanted a name easier to pronounce and remember for foreigners. There was also a nationalist motive: Chopin was French-Polish. Many Polish people suffer from an inferiority complex vis-a-vis other European nations, and can't bear thinking of sharing Polish icons with others. Making Chopin patron of *Poland's* busiest airport was supposed to show there was more Polish in him than French. (In a similar vein, a politician of the 2015-2023 ruling populist party publicly claimed in 2016 that sophisticated Polish people taught the disgusting, uncouth French how to use forks in the 16th century...).

"We're buying a hotel. You inn?"
"Yes! Sounds suite!"

(I had to resort to this.)

I rarely credit gripes about proper noun trivia answers, but QDOBA doesn't seem quite fair. Of course, trivia master than I am, I got it immediately, but if I hadn't have heard of it, I would never have gotten it. Q and D next to each other? I'm at least expecting letters that would be found next to each other in the wild...
There's maybe some overlap, but logic gates are more in the realm of electrical engineering rather than computer programming.

I‚Äôve never cried over a crossword puzzle before, but you got me Deb. I‚Äôll never forget those words and that great hero. 
Excellent Friday puzzle.
My emu is solemn today.

Nice themeless, Jake.  For what it's worth, I think your original clues for 25A: [Get to know inside out?] and especially 45A: [Championship rings?] were better than the ones that were used. 

Also, great clue for SEA LEGS.

Well.. for once the puzzle was not my primary focus this morning, and I had to look some things up but managed to get through it. Nice puzzle for the most part. As usual a number of things that weren't dawning on me from the clues but finally came to mind with some crosses. 

Things are about to get a whole lot more interesting here. Flooding, winds, tree limbs, power outages... who knows. I'll check back in later (if I'm still connected) and let you know how it went. 

...

NW corner was bizarre; another one I put down to trying to solve from overseas, but have seen a couple of other comments mention the same. Bad beat? Sounds like when autogenerated subtitles go awry. Some nice clues elsewhere and the clues that didn‚Äôt make it past the edit were better than the ones that ended up in the puzzle, so I‚Äôll assume this is what happened in the NW (mark of a tipsy drummer?)
My best Friday so far.  I got about 80% filled without lookups.  To the best of my recollection, I've never solved a Friday or Saturday without help, but my day is coming!

Tricky Friday full of misdirects and floating black squares.  

Surprised to have finished in 7 seconds under my average Friday time - thought this one was a bear.

Bravo, Mr. Bunch!
Fun puzzle! Got lost in the NE with bILLIONAIRE and dali, but managed to find my way to the VICTORY LAP.
QDOBA sounds like one of those randomly generated Chinese brand names selling house slippers, mouse pads, and inexplicable 24x36 inch prints of a brick on Amazon.

I found this one tricky and slower than normal for a Friday, but admittedly my concentration was split as I was watching a football game while solving. Once again the NW was my biggest sticking point.  I had never heard the expression BADBEAT  as term for a poker loss, or any kind of loss for that matter, and GOTEAMGO, although perfectly logical, eluded me for a good while. Debugging soft wear for MOSQUITONET was quite fine, and I enjoyed SEALEGS for good standing at sea, even if the match between clue and answer was perhaps a little askew.

There‚Äôs something peaceful about seeing those floating black squares. It puts me in a lovely frame of mind to approach the puzzle. A lovely counter to Helene‚Äôs stormy weather outside.

This puzzle gave me some rich resistance from things I don‚Äôt know, from clues that would work for several answers, so couldn‚Äôt be filled in immediately, and other clues that flummoxed me until crosses rescued me. Thus, my workout ethic was easily satisfied.

It‚Äôs hard not to adore a puzzle that‚Äôs cheery (GO TEAM GO), beery (ALEKEG), and query (AREe YOU IN?). I also liked the symmetrical pair of lovelies (LYRICAL, BASMATI), and the food-centric southeast (CUPCAKES, CREAMERY, PEA, PARERS, ICERS).

Jake, you gave me many smiles in your last puzzle (a debut), one of them being [Hunks of plastic] for KENS. Here I am, smiling again after this one. Three‚Äôs the charm ‚Äî looking forward to your next.  Thank you for a splendid outing!

With GUSTO and zeal we WINSGOLD.

This puzzle is jake with us.

Thank you..... Jake

Very enjoyable puzzle, even if I didn't get the gold star. 

I had hADBEAT for1A as in "I HAD him BEAT but then I folded". That's a tough loss.

I figured a hONEIN was a type of film cut where you hone in on something or someone. Made sense at the time.

"It ices! It dices! It pares! It's the new Cruciverb¬Æ from NYT industries! No kitchen should be without one! Let Pop band ABC show you how it's done: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VYb1bcFcopc . . . And if you call within the next thirty minutes, we'll send you a *second* Cruciverb¬Æ free--you just pay shipping and handling.

If you haven't heard of it, you haven't heard of it, but for what it's worth Qdoba has over 750 locations in the country. So it's not as obscure as some commenters think it is. (The name is made up, though; it was created to avoid potential trademark infringement from other restaurants.)
Very fresh puzzle. I thought the clueing was a bit too straightforward for a Friday, but liked ‚Äúdebugging soft wear‚Äù and ‚Äúgood standing in the Navy.‚Äù

One nit to pick: SPOT ADS aren't a thing. An ad is a spot, and a spot is an ad. I've worked in broadcast media for 15 years on the advertising end of things, and I've never heard anyone refer to a "spot ad."

But points for QDOBA. I used to go to one when I lived in Sioux Falls. It's better than Chipotle!

Very nice Friday puzzle. That QDOBA (which I didn't know) in the center is rather striking. 

Solved this unaided, but took more than thirty minutes.

Discouraging on first pass but I chipped away at it.  Was really stuck in the NW.  Went to google to confirm ATTILA (2D) was correct, and the search results accidentally revealed BASMATI (4D) as the rice variety.  I had tried ARBORIO and RISOTTO and was getting nowhere.  So many types of rice!

Favorite answer was 24D MOSQUITONET.  Made me smile, thinking about my park ranger son sleeping under one in remote Western canyons.

Welp, I guess we all have to start playing poker.  Seems to be coming up a lot, recently. And those who don't drink beer need to start that too. I'm terrible at card games but I do like a nice bitter IPA so I'm batting 50  percent, right?
Liked clue for 47D (doh!) but 24D really nailed it. (Even though, like many others, I thought that restaurant had to be QU.... Didn't help that my inner 8-year-old boy wanted the onion-cutting clue to relate to farting. But that's "cutting the cheese", isn't it?)

So I'm trying to guess what a BAD BEAT at poker is.  I mean I already know you're seated on a chair that's painted green, but what else?  You had a huge bet sitting on the table?  You lost by a whisker -- three queens to three kings?  I don't play poker, but I sort of have the feeling that this may be a made-up phrase that nobody says.

Not a good idea to put questionable or controversial fill at 1A.  Other than that, though, I found this an enjoyable puzzle.  It seemed fairly easy for a Friday -- except for the places that weren't.  I made my grid very messy by filling in two answers in very dark ink that were wrong:  ON AUTOmatic before ON AUTOPILOT and, spurred on by the initial "Y", I had YES AND NO instead of YOUR CALL for "I could go either way on that".

I liked the clues for VICTORY LAPS and SEA LEGS.  But many clues seemed quite easy for a Friday -- CHOPIN in particular.  I very much appreciated the lack of names and the very clean grid.  And will I EVER learn to spell ATTILA?  I knew him early on, but waited to write him in until I could confirm the spelling.  I'm a really good speller, but this is a blind spot.  Does anyone know a mnemonic?

Anyway -- smooth, clean and enjoyable.

I hate when I get a BAD HAND.
Brown BASMATI rice is a household staple here.  It is also helpful in solving crosswords.

Six years' AGE GAP did not seem too serious in 1979, but it's a little more impactful down the road....  We don't use little phrases like "TO DIE FOR" in case it's too close to home.

QDOBA was kinda tough.  Wanted Quizno....tested some creative spellings.  

If you're a ZILLIONAIRE, maybe you think you should be a co-president...  I am reminded of the novel _The Octopus_ .....only I think the situation is worse.

Hey, all you Tarheels--better check your voter registration, 'cause you might have been purged.  The PARERS have been hard at work.  

Wow, who knew Jake Bunch had constructed his puzzle with so much apt and timely material?!

I just wanted to point out that MOthballing fit in 24D, and made perfect sense to me. I liked "dusk TIL dawn," and I was just thinking of the Tarantino movie yesterday, although he spelled it TILL for some reason. Still one of my favorite vampire movies, right after Lost Boys.
Pretty easy, though BILLIONAIRE instead of ZILLIONAIRE slowed me down for a spell

Tough and fun workout with the top row the last to fall but it did take several sittings to complete.  

That makes up for going down in flames on today's Mini.  First time fail.  Nice one Christina. 

Much preferred Jake's original clues but can see why the editors looked the other way on the one for UGLY.  

Well done and thanks.

Interesting that QDOBA was so troubling for so many. I didn't have a problem with it and wondered if the restaurant hadn't fully penetrated the US. It turns out they have locations in 47 states. Many states with just a few locations though, so maybe that's the issue. Like many others, the NW was a bear for me, but somehow I got it done.... enjoyable Friday for me!

The only way I could "solve" this puzzle was with the help of Autocheck.
Was fun! Thank you NYT!

emu food
Thought I had something wrong for sure, because what's an ALEKEG?...Doh!!
SE corner was the last to fall for me but I don't get STS (26d).

Super smooth and satisfying solve.  Less of a head-scratcher than what I usually expect for Friday, but definitely not one to be attempted ONAUTOPILOT.  So many fun entries -- TIL that CHOPIN has a namesake airport; loved the clues for MOSQUITONET and GOTEAMGO; the crossings of ZESTY/TODIEFOR and CUPCAKES/CREAMERY made my mouth water.  Nicely done, Jake Bunch -- take a couple VICTORYLAPS!

Enjoyed today‚Äôs puzzle, but had one of those clueless moments - even after solving it with the crosses - where I just couldn‚Äôt figure out ‚ÄúBONEIN‚Äù - thinking it might be an obscure German cut: ‚ÄúBO NEIN‚Äù or ‚ÄúBON EIN‚Äù. But eventually I saw it ‚Ä¶

I‚Äôm learning a lot of US English! But the popsicle stand was a beezer. By the way, British English spells it ‚Äòtill‚Äô (but ‚Äòuntil‚Äô) and ‚Äòpeaky‚Äô means unwell although I‚Äôve not heard of ‚Äòpeaked‚Äô (and ‚Äòpiqued‚Äô is different again). The mosquito net clue is more like what I‚Äôm used to (see Quck Crosswod in The Guardian).

Crossword constructors frequently approach me and say, "Sir, I would love to put the lyrical entry INTEGRATED DEVELOPMENT ENVIRONMENTS in one of my puzzles, but I hesitate to do so without a worthy clue. Could you help me? I just have to add that you're much more handsome in person!"

And I reply, "Yes. Yes I am. But I don't have a clue."

But now I do!

[Debugging's oft where?]

Arborio...no. Jasmine...no. BASMATI!...oof. That's a snippet of how this whole puzzle went down for me ‚Äì most definitely not on the constructor's wavelength, and a clear departure from yesterday's puzzle. As John Denver would say, "Some days are diamonds, some days are stone..." https://youtu.be/pUt2zDrddIQ?feature=shared ... and some days are gold, but not this one! Thank you for the challenge, Mr. Bunch. You win. ;-)

Late puzzle find - inspired by my compulsive letter counting. Thought of some song lyrics from the Sound of Music* and... it dawned on me that: 

ADEERAFEMALEDEER
ADROPOFGOLDENSUN
and
ANAMEICALLMYSELF 

... are all 16 letters. And, of course if you drop the 'a' from the front they're all 15 letters. And.... yep - those (without the 'a') were the theme answers in a Tuesday puzzle from May 22, 2007 by Roger Wolff. Oh, and DOREMI and EDELWEISS were also answers in that one. 

*and.. THESOUNDOFMUSIC is also 15 letters. It's been an answer in 24 puzzles. 

I'm done. 

..

Starting with the positive, MOSQUITO NET was a great clue, truly top notch and why crosswords are fun.

However, "reprehensible" for UGLY may be the most offensive clue I've ever seen in a puzzle. Ugliness isn't a choice, one should not be condemned for it. If you're going for the more obscure meanings of ugly, please use a synonym rather than a judgement.

What region refers to Paring Knives as PARERS? I have never heard this before and after googling, assume it is from the French, so Quebec or Louisiana?

ALE KEG is simply lazy, nobody refers to Kegs this way and the clue could just as accurately refer to Lagers, Sours, Pilseners, Stouts, etc. Similarly, SPOT ADS are AD SPOTS. If you need to reverse the order to make it fit, then include that in the clue.

So, as a daily lurker but rare commenter in these parts, I read all the comments sure that someone else would ask the question on my mind. As no one did, I shall. 

Do you all actually WEAR mosquito nets?

I had never heard of a BAD BEAT (I haven‚Äôt played poker in 50 years and can barely remember the ranking of the hands). It wasn‚Äôt until IGLOO that I started filling in the grid, but then I zoomed through it (despite thinking first of DAL√ç rather than MIR√ì). 

TO DIE FOR reminds me of the Gus Van Sant movie with Nicole Kidman and Matt Dillon. I remember really liking that 30 years ago. I could see it again; it‚Äôs got a great cast. 

According to Google maps, all the QDOBA restaurants in Austin (where I used to live) are ‚Äúpermanently closed.‚Äù But I got it with only a letter or two. 

My biggest slowdown was misspelling ZILLIONAIRE. It didn‚Äôt fit the first time I tried it.

Thanks for the fun, Mr. Bunch!

Great puzzle - I needed some help from the article and comments to confirm and fill in some answers. I struggle to understand ILL for ‚ÄúPeaks‚Äù clue - does the answer ILL mean ‚ÄúI‚Äôll‚Äù for I will? Or does being I‚Äôll refer to peaks? I‚Äôm confused and only got this final answer thanks to the verticals :-)

An enjoyable puzzle. Solved this one is less time than average, but it wasn't exactly a piece of cake, either. Lots of fun clues.
I especially like the fact that there are few pop culture references. So often I need to look up movie or song titles, brand names, etc. that I've never heard of. Today's puzzle only had one clue with such a reference, but I was able to figure it out with cross fill. (Living where I do, there's no need to step into a restaurant chain to get Mexican food! I prefer to support local businesses, anyway.)

Ah, this is one where my mileage varied.  I‚Äôve never pared potatoes (though that isn‚Äôt to say others haven‚Äôt), and ‚ÄúALE KEG‚Äù made me feel a kinda way and gave my eyebrows an arching workout.  Otherwise, I offer my usual admiration to the clever folk who make these puzzles for my enjoyment.  Y‚Äôall amaze me.

Fellow cruciverbalists, especially y‚Äôall further Southeast than I, take good care of yourselves.
Why use the word ‚Äúreal‚Äù in 8D clue?
Can someone explain ‚Äú1st, 2nd, etc‚Äù‚Äôs answer of STS to me?
The only clue I was annoyed by the 1st, 2nd 3rd clue.  I had SEQ(uence)  at first but still don‚Äôt know what STS is supposed to mean
After a 979 day streak, this one very nearly did me in. Twice my normal Friday time. Who knew that BASMATI, JASMINE, and RISOTTO, and ARBORIO could cause such multiverse befuddlement at 4 down‚Ä¶.

I guess I‚Äôm old enough that I‚Äôve never encountered ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs cutting onions?‚Äù as internet speak so I just assumed with the question mark that it couldn‚Äôt LITERALLY be talking about someone cutting onions‚Ä¶

So, yesterday (JST) I had 3 or so posts in a thread discussing poker hands and BAD BEAT.

It was civil, innocuous, rather informative, I thought.

Wake up this morning and it appears to be deleted...

Did it go off on some wild and offensive tangent while I slept? I have no idea why it would disappear.

I did not know the story behind LET‚ÄôS ROLL. Thanks for posting the link to the History Channel video clip. I remember 9/11 vividly and that piece brought chills and tears to my eyes. 

Definitely a challenging puzzle for me, needed help to finish.
TIL is a misspelling. The preposition is spelled "till". It is not a contraction of "until". "Until" is derived from "till", not the other way around.
About 50% over average for me. Was very pleased when I finally got it. Thanks for a fun puzzle.

(This was originally slated as a reply to someone's complaint about ALEKEG, but I thought I give it its own thread.)

I'll say this again (and probably again and again).  Pretty much every day there is a crossword answer I've never heard of, but am able to fill it in either because the answer has a shred of reasonableness (such as ALEKEG) or it just seems to be the most likely answer given all the pieces of the puzzle.  At the end of the day, it doesn't really matter if this crossword is the only place this specific string of letters has ever been in print.  Just accept that you have never heard of it, and that whether or not it is in use somewhere is immaterial.  Sure would cut down on a lot of comments.

A little late to this party, but I can't let LET'S ROLL go by without comment. It continues to cause unbearable sadness for me. 

Just a few months before 9/11 we had a reunion dinner for a special group of junior high school students from my school (for older NYC current or former residents, SP classes), and this was 37 years after graduation.

One of the classmates who attended was Mickey Rothenberg, also in my H.S. graduation class. He was the businessman who was executed by the terrorists before Todd Beamer used those immortal words. 

On 9/11 I always say a special prayer in his memory.
That was the longest 23 minutes I‚Äôve ever hard but it felt so good to crack this one
@Wendy Laubach Or was it difficult because the clues *weren‚Äôt* great?

@ER No, I thought they were clever clues, hard to guess, but satisfying once I got them.  And hardly any clunkers among them of the "middle name of obscure rapper" or "obscure river in obscure country" variety.

@joel88s 

OK, we won't tell you Helene is in today's puzzle.

Emus go home...
@Dave Rosenbaum wouldn‚Äôt that require five aces and five kings?

@Dave Rosenbaum 
And, in Texas Hold ‚ÄòEm, it‚Äôs a term often used when an opponent makes their winning hand on the river (the final card dealt).

@Michael Ostroff 

Not the way I take it.

Full House kings full of aces = KKKAA

Full House aces full of kings = AAAKK
@Michael Ostroff. Texas Holdem. Two kings and an ace on the table. I have a king and an ace, he (expletive deleted) has two aces.

@Al  in Pittsburgh 

You just perfectly illustrated Michael's point.

5 kings and 5 aces

an impossibility (unless playing with wilds)

Apologies to Al in Pittsburgh


Patrick's explanation works


provided the game is hold'em

@Francis 

But that wouldn't be a beat

nor a loss

if they came up in different deals

Al was correct, I was confused, Patrick cleared things up

@Dave S a bad beat isn‚Äôt really just losing with a good hand. It‚Äôs losing when you outplayed your opponent in the sense made  decisions that were in expectation right, while your opponent made decisions that were in expectation wrong, yet got lucky in the end, often by getting the only card that could help them on the river (the last card dealt). The beat is rendered ‚Äúbad‚Äù by a sense of injustice.

@Bill in Yokohama 

D'oh.  Of course you and Francis are right.
My own reply shows it.

Even playing around with wild cards, 
assuming the original example was the best possible evaluation of the hands,
couldn't make it work.

Sorry.  No excuse.

@Annie 

Congrats on the streak!
Way to go, @Annie!

@Annie 
Great accomplishment!

@Annie 

Great streak.  On to 10,000!

@Annie 

The only way I'll ever get to 1000 is in binary, which is the same as 8, decimal.

@Annie Congratulations on your streak! What a fantastic achievement and dedication to complete with no errors every day!

I reached 1000 yesterday too :)

@Paul 

Well, then, congratulations to you, too, Paul!

@Annie Wow ... congratulations Annie - fabulous. I've got a live streak of 20 going at the moment, so a long LONG way to go to catch you. I solve on my own, with no dictionaries, wiki, or other help. Hope your next 1,000 is just as much fun üåû

Thanks everyone! To be clear though, I have zero shame in looking something up if I get stuck haha. I am of the mind looking things up is learning for the next time üòä so it might not meet everyone‚Äôs definition of a gold star puzzle, but in the end it‚Äôs just about taking a little time for myself everyday to do something I love.

I am so impressed with people who maintain their streaks with no mistakes or look ups! But that‚Äôs not always me, and it especially wasn‚Äôt at first

I want to encourage anyone who feels like they can‚Äôt get them perfect without asking for a little help (be it from friends or the internet!) to be still be proud of starting a routine. it‚Äôs all for the love of puzzles, after all üñ§

@B I noticed the isolated squares in threes that are hugging AMA, STS, HER, OVA. This helped me see that this grid is very close to having 90¬∞ symmetry instead of the usual 180¬∞, with only the two isolated squares above the D and below the B in QDOBA spoiling it. And there are only 30 black squares in total, which is relatively low. It's an unusual grid, and I found it interesting.

Steven,

I have absolutely no clue what any of that means, save that ‚Äúvictory lapse‚Äù is a pun (unknown context). Hints, anyone?

Really brings back memories of emails from departmental deputy ministers and the like. 

(and of some of my posts here  =)

@JohnWM 
I direct your attention to the date of the memo: it's from 1984, by George Orwell. Minitrue is "newspeak" for Ministry of Truth. Steven's post was double plus good.
@JohnWM This may help: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministries_in_Nineteen_Eighty-Four emu food more emu food

@Striker 

Yeah it's another of those ubiquitous and yet anonymous "is it a sub shop?  is it Mexican food?" chains that almost no one you know has ever been to.

And yeah, you reminded me how much I didn't like the onions clue; I expected more.  :(

Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(I do this instead of emuing)

@Striker 

It may not be the greatest of clues, but I read it as a question:  "Who is the person who is cutting onions?"
And the answer would be the DICER.  

In other words, the ? is part of the clue phrase.
@Striker I was hoping DINAH was the answer about onions. I mean, someone‚Äôs in the kitchen with her and she must be doing something in there.

@Striker 

Well, I don't really know, either!

That was just the way it occurred to me.  It's not like I evaluated the two ways of looking at it.

What I do *think* I know, though, is that there are a lot of "unwritten" rules that everyone "knows" about crosswords.  The thing is, unwritten rules are sure to be violated.

About the only rules I really lean on are verb tense and singular/plural.  Even then it's a little vague to me in certain circumstances.

So the bottom line is that while many commenters complain about many "violations of the rules", no one has ever been established as an enforcement mechanism. 

So complaints are going to go unanswered.

"I‚Äôve never heard of Q DOBA in my life. East Coast thing? Mid West?" Striker, QDOBA is national, but there aren't that many of them. I've never seen one in the wild; there doesn't seem to be one in Manhattan. There may not be one near you. https://locations.qdoba.com/us.html

@Striker 

Deb‚Äôs column made me aware that ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs cutting onions?‚Äù (with the ‚Äú?‚Äù) is a contemporary idiom to convey the notion that someone is emotionally moved by something (perhaps to tears) but wants to deny it.

@Warren 

Thanks, Warren. I was more confused by usage of the question mark, as a general ‚Äúcrossword rule‚Äù than the idiom. 

I thought question mark always meant wordplay. I actually had DICER but I deleted it early on because I didn‚Äôt think it was a ‚Äúquestion mark worthy‚Äù response before eventually going back to it. 

Now I‚Äôve learned that sometimes a question mark is just a question mark. 

Add it to the quiver and keep on solving!

I figure Chipotle isn‚Äôt exactly shaking in their botas, fretting over a QDOBA take over.

@Francis

Dear lord. This is just for fun and life‚Äôs too short.

@Esmerelda your explanation is very understandable but the tragedy is that ‚Äúhone in‚Äù has incorrectly become the broadly used expression when it should be HOME IN. The word ‚Äúhone‚Äù is kinda related (you‚Äôre sharpening something literally or figuratively, so it‚Äôs getting closer to what is ideal and what you want) but the correct ‚Äúhome in‚Äù refers to getting closer to home (and therefore your target) as exemplified by a ‚Äúhoming pigeon‚Äù or ‚Äúhoming beacon‚Äù. The (mis)use of ‚Äúhone in‚Äù has gotten so widespread that it even infected your logic on that clue :-(

@BamBam 

UGLY doesn't have to refer to the looks a person was born with.  No one would call Quasimodo reprehensible when they mean he wasn't attractive.

But reprehensible actions and behaviors are unquestionably UGLY.  And if just one sense of a word is synonymous to another, that's fine for crosswords.  No one is going to think that people who aren't the most attractive are reprehensible.

PARERS exist and are called that.  Just Google it and click on Shopping to see many examples of them.  "Paring knife" is more common, but that doesn't matter when deciding whether PARERS are a thing.

A SPOT AD is broadcast during an AD SPOT.  My sense of a SPOT AD is one that is slotted into a spot individually, rather than as part of a package deal made between a manufacturer and a network.  Most of the political ads you see nowadays are SPOT ADS.  

As for ALE KEG, be wary of saying "nobody refers to..."  Google "ale keg" (with the quotes) and you'll find sites where they do use these two words together as a phrase.  You may not have heard of it, but that doesn't mean nobody ever says it.  It may be rare, but it doesn't have to be super common for it to be fine in the puzzle.  If I say I have an ALE KEG, do you understand what I have?  That's the benchmark, no higher than that.

@So It's a 19th-century usage that perhaps survives mostly in the South.  The old-fashioned rule was to pronounce the -ed as a separate syllable when using a past participle as an adjective.  It survives now only in a few words, like "aged," "beloved," "blessed," "learned," "naked," "ragged," "rugged," "sacred," "supposed," "wretched."  In old books (and Shakespeare) you may see a participle written as "belov'd," to indicate that you're not intended to separate the pronunciation of the "ed."
@Wendy Laubach Thanks for the explanation. I love finding out about the history of language.

Paul, TIL (as 'til) is spelled correctly. The question mark on the clue suggested to me the editors' acknowledgement that the idiom properly uses "till." People often ask which is the correct synonym of until, till, ‚Äôtil, or ‚Äôtill? Many assume that till is an abbreviated form of until. In fact, it is a distinct word that existed in English at least a century before until, both as a preposition meaning ‚Äúto‚Äù and as a conjunction meaning ‚Äúuntil.‚Äù It has seen continuous use in English since the 12th century and is a perfectly legitimate synonym of until. ‚ÄôTil and ‚Äôtill are much newer words, having appeared in the language only in the 19th and 20th centuries, respectively. Both are variant spellings of until and till. Writers of usage guides have roundly condemned ‚Äôtill as a barbarism (apparently because it seems to have added a superfluous L to the end of until). ‚ÄôTil, for its part, has been deemed inappropriate in formal writing. In summary, until and till can be used freely and interchangeably, but you will probably want to avoid ‚Äôtill and use ‚Äôtil advisedly. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/until

@Barry Ancona your copy/pasted paragraphs seem to support my claim. The reason 'til "has been deemed inappropriate in formal writing" is because it's not a legitimate word. It's a spelling error made by someone hearing "till" and mistakenly assuming it's an abbreviation of "until". It's no different from any other instance of someone incorrectly guessing the spelling of a word they hear. E.g., some people hear "pass muster" and write "pass mustard", but that doesn't mean the NYT crossword should clue the word "mustard" as "formal military inspection".

'til is a word in M-W (same source).

variants or til
variant spellings of till entry 1 sense 1, till entry 2

: until

Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(I do this instead of emuing)

@Grumpy 

I learned this long ago, and it more than anything else got me to the point where I no longer ever fear not being able to finish a puzzle:

When there's something in the puzzle that not everyone would know or could reason through, the crosses will always all be gettable.

Here, the crosses are MOSQUITO NET, DICER, I WON'T, AD LIB and ZILLIONAIRE.

Of that set, only DICER is, to make a weak joke, dicey.  Buy if you get the I, C, E and R (or at least a few of them), you can reason out the rest of the word.

If you can't get MOSQUITO NET and the rest, the problem isn't just QDOBA...but it's not the puzzle's fault.

Of course if you want to kill you kid, just leave a loaded gun laying around.  Again, suffered enough.
